titles.title: The phonology of Àbèsàbèsì vowel harmony. Unpublished PhD dissertation

record.notes: ABSTRACT: ---------------------------------------------- - TOPIC: vowel harmony in Abesabesi - FRAMEWORK: optimality theory - QUESTION: test the adequacy of OT to account for the 3 Abesabesi harmonies (viz. ATR, Low-Vowel and ATR+ Rounding) - OT-CONSTRAINTS: -- IDENT-IO[high], IDENT-IO[back], IDENT-IO[round], Align [A]R, Align [A]L, Align [-low]R, Align [round]L, Align [round]L if Hi, *Rt/Hi, *[A]/low, *[A]R, *[A]L - constraints are ranked differently in each language 1.7 SCOPE/1.8.1 DATA COLLECTION--------------------------------- - 1000 respondents in nine communities - free speeches in informal gatherings - audio recordings, transcribed Domains of Vowel Harmony: - root harmony - affixation: -- verbal nouns (no harmony) -- verbal focus - pronouns -- sub (3rd pl) -- ob/poss (1sg, 2sg, 3pl) - tam markers

titles.title: Àbèsàbèsì Orthography : A Proposal
titles.secondary-title: IOSR Journal Of Humanities And Social Science

periodical.full-title: IOSR Journal Of Humanities And Social Science

record.label: Abesabesi;Dialects;Orthography;Tone
record.abstract: This paper proposes orthography for Àbèsàbèsì a language known as Akpes in Literature with ethnographic identity ibe. Agoyi 2008 proposed the name Àbèsàbèsì formed from the root morpheme Àbèsì ‘we’ because it is the only identity accepted by all the nine communities that speak variant of the language. All speakers of the language are aware of the endangered status of the language hence the need to have a writing system that will be used in writing literature in the language for teaching and documenting the language. In line with Nigeria National Policy on Education 2004section 4 subsection 19e states that the medium of instruction in the primary school shall be the language of the environment for the first three years. During this period, English shall be thought as a subject. To be able to implement this policy there is the need to propose orthography for the languages to assist speakers of minority languages who feel the need to safe their languages from death. Since the speakers are familiar with the Yoruba orthography, this paper proposes graphemes that are close to the Yoruba graphemes. The orthography is based mostly on a co-language orthography principle. The proposed graphemes ware tested with literate speakers of the language. In all 37 graphemes are proposed for the consonants, vowels and tone phonemes the various dialects attest. This research is sponsored by Àbèsàbèsì Language Development committee.

titles.title: Morphology of Àbèsàbèsì Numerals: A Case Study of Èkiròmì
titles.secondary-title: International Journal of Business and Social Science

periodical.full-title: International Journal of Business and Social Science

record.label: Abesabesi;Ekiromi;Morphology;Numerals
record.abstract: This paper explores the mathematical conceptualization and arithmetical operations that are expressed by the linguistic forms of the numeral systems of ‘Àbè sà bè si’ (Known in literature as Akpes (etymology ibe), Èkiròmì lect in particular) a member of the Edoid language family of Niger Congo language. Direction of Èkiròmì counting is from left to right. The morphology of the numerals indicates È kiròmì basic elements as 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10, 20 and three basic points of bundles as10, 20 and 400. Thus African Languages may start with the same basic elements but combine them in intricate and create ways and patterns to produce unique and effective numeral systems cf. Oyebade and Agoyi (in preparation).

titles.title: Language, Invasion and Insecurity: The History of Àbèsàbèsì
titles.secondary-title: American Journal of Social Issues and Humanities

periodical.full-title: American Journal of Social Issues and Humanities

record.label: Abesabesi
record.abstract: Language is a unifying factor in human society. The genesis of any nation and people threatened by lack of trust, insecurity and struggle may be traced to language related problem. While developed nations in the world guide and develop their languages, informed nations with many languages often allow each linguistic group to develop her linguistic wealth alongside the national lingua-franca ( e.g USA and UK). Nigeria is a nation well known for its linguistic diversity. This paper examines the linguistic phenomenon linked to the History of Àbèsàbèsì, a language spoken in nine communities in Akoko (North West, Ondo State) and the implication of such linguistic indices for the unity of Nigeria.

titles.title: Ǹń Kpasi Àbèsàbèsì: Mo Gbọ́ Àbèsàbèsì: I Understand Àbèsàbèsì
titles.secondary-title: International Journal of Humanities and Social Science Invention

periodical.full-title: International Journal of Humanities and Social Science Invention

record.label: Abesabesi
record.abstract: This booklet tests Agoyi 2012 roposed orthography for Àbèsàbèsì a language known as Akpes in Literature with ethnographic identity ibe. In Agoyi 2012 I mentioned that Agoyi 2008 proposed the name Àbèsàbèsì formed from the root morpheme Àbèsì ‘we’ because it is the only identity accepted by all the nine communities that speak variant of the language. After proposing orthography for an unwritten language there is the need to subject the orthography to test; such test will help to determine how easy to learn the writing system will be for the targeted learners. The first edition of the booklet was printed in 2012 in Ikare Akoko Ondo State, Nigeria in honour of the Akala of Ikaramu on his ìwúyè and first Installation ceremony. This edition came as a result of demands for a review of the first edition by Àbèsàbèsì sons and daughters at home and in diaspora. The booklet is my contribution to implementation Nigeria National Policy on Education 2004 section 4 subsection 19e which states that ‘the medium of instruction in the primary school shall be the language of the environment for the first three years. During this period, English shall be thought as a subject’. The booklet will assist speakers of Àbèsàbèsì a minority languages who feel the need to safe their languages from death. To assist the learner comprehension of the content, the booklet adopts a trilingual model: Àbèsàbèsì, Yoruba, and English. The booklet teaches the alphabets, parts of the body, some essential questions and greetings in the language. The research is sponsored by Àbèsàbèsì Language Development committee.

titles.title: A comparative reconstruction of Akpes lects, Akoko North, Ondo State. MA thesis

record.notes: Methodology: - comparative method - reconstruct a proto-language - revised swadesh 100-word list (must be Ibadan 400 inferred from data) Findings: - Lexicostatistics: -- Akunnu and Iludotun closest relatives -- Abesabesi is language cluster --- reasons: mutual intellegibility not between all lects --- similarities sometimes below 80 % (between 69 and 95%) -- no basis for drawing a tree diagram, as two methods brought different results. Phonology: - Syllable: V, CV, N-, VN-, CVC - Words: nouns and verbs begin with V, N- or CV - Vowels: 7 oral, 5 nasal (no õ, ẽ) - distribution of vowels: -- all vowels occur in medial and final position -- all oral vowels occur word-initially, except in Ase, Ikaram and Gedegede, where /u/ does not occur word-initially. - Language does not show any vowel harmony (he means root harmony) - consonants: -- max 23 + 5 labialized -- nasal harmony -- allophones j/ɲ, ŋ/ɣ -- labialization: b, k, g, tʃ, h (only in Ase, Akunnu, Esuku, Daja and Ilodun) --- interpreted as single phonemic unit, no process of labialization -- v, p, bʷ, gʷ, tʃʷ, kʷ, hʷ not in all dialects -- nasalization --- nasal epenthesis as a result of nasalized vowels before consonants
record.research-notes: Methodology: - comparative method - reconstruct a proto-language - revised swadesh 100-word list (must be Ibadan 400 inferred from data) Findings: - Lexicostatistics: -- Akunnu and Iludotun closest relatives -- Abesabesi is language cluster --- reasons: mutual intellegibility not between all lects --- similarities sometimes below 80 % (between 69 and 95%) -- no basis for drawing a tree diagram, as two methods brought different results. Phonology: - Syllable: V, CV, N-, VN-, CVC - Words: nouns and verbs begin with V, N- or CV - Vowels: 7 oral, 5 nasal (no õ, ẽ) - distribution of vowels: -- all vowels occur in medial and final position -- all oral vowels occur word-initially, except in Ase, Ikaram and Gedegede, where /u/ does not occur word-initially. - Language does not show any vowel harmony (he means root harmony) - consonants: -- max 23 + 5 labialized -- nasal harmony -- allophones j/ɲ, ŋ/ɣ -- labialization: b, k, g, tʃ, h (only in Ase, Akunnu, Esuku, Daja and Ilodun) --- interpreted as single phonemic unit, no process of labialization -- v, p, bʷ, gʷ, tʃʷ, kʷ, hʷ not in all dialects -- nasalization --- nasal epenthesis as a result of nasalized vowels before consonants

titles.title: Ethnologue: Languages of the World
Assessing endangerment: Expanding Fishman's GIDS
titles.secondary-title: Revue Roumaine de Linguistique

periodical.full-title: Revue Roumaine de Linguistique

record.label: Language Endangerment;Language Vitality
record.abstract: Fishman's 8-level Graded Intergenerational Disruption Scale (GIDS) has served as the seminal and best-known evaluative framework of language endangerment for nearly two decades. It has provided the theoretical underpinnings for most practitioners of language revitalization. More recently, UNESCO has developed a 6-level scale of endangerment. Ethnologue uses yet another set of five categories to characterize language vitality. In this paper, these three evaluative systems are aligned to form an amplified and elaborated evaluative scale of 13 levels, the E(xpanded) GIDS. Any known language, including those languages for which there are no longer speakers, can be categorized by using the resulting scale (unlike the GIDS). A language can be evaluated in terms of the EGIDS by answering five key questions regarding the identity function, vehicularity, state of intergenerational language transmission, literacy acquisition status, and a societal profile of generational language use. With only minor modification the EGIDS can also be applied to languages which are being revitalized.

titles.title: Language diversification in the Akoko area of Western Nigeria
titles.secondary-title: Archaeology and Language IV. Language change and cultural transformation

periodical.full-title: Archaeology and Language IV. Language change and cultural transformation

titles.title: On the linguistic situation in Àkókó
titles.secondary-title: California Linguistic Notes

periodical.full-title: California Linguistic Notes

record.label: Abesabesi;Akoko;Language Vitality
record.abstract: It is a general belief among the non-Àkókó people and linguists who are not conversant with Àkókó land to assume that Àkókó land is linguistically homogeneous. That is why they erroneously refer to speech forms in the land as ‘Yorùbá Àkókó’ and or Àkókó dialect’. However, this paper shows that Àkókó land is not linguistically homogeneous, as speech forms in the area belong to the Yoruboid, Edoid, and Akokoid branches of the YEAI subgroup of West Benue-Congo language family. Introduction

Research Findings: - Akpes is acquired simoultaneously with Yoruba - Superior ability in Yoruba compared with Akpes - better Yoruba if: old, better-educated, better jobs - better Akpes if: old 5.1: Language Use: - "Yoruba is already gaining a foothold in the family, and in other contexts where one would expect Akpes." (538)

titles.title: Basic oral language documentation
titles.secondary-title: Language Documentation & Conservation

periodical.full-title: Language Documentation & Conservation

record.label: Annotation;BOLD;LDD
record.abstract: Since at least 1992, when Michael Krauss presented the topic of language endangerment in Language, linguists have been wrestling with the problem that languages are disappearing from the earth faster than they can be satisfactorily documented. This paper advocates a methodology for documenting languages that minimizes the use of high-cost means of recording comments on recorded language data (written annotation), focusing instead on making low-cost means (oral annotation) more effective. I present here a brief history of the origins of the method, detail how the annotation process is executed, and evaluate its effectiveness in several dimensions. Finally, since it is an emerging technique, I will also discuss the directions in which the research on this methodology ought to develop.

titles.title: Tone in the phonology, lexicon and grammar of Ikaan. PhD Thesis

record.notes: 2.5 GRAMMATICAL BACKGROUND 2.5.1 PHONOLOGY CONSONANTS - only pulmonic - no voiced fricatives - voiced and voiceless approximants - s, l, ŋ only in loan words - p in loan words and in òpú 'ten' - dʒ may also be palatal plosive VOWELS - height, fronting, contrastive ATR value, length and nasality - all contrasting possibilities of oral/nasal, +/-ATR, long short attested except /ẽ:, ʊ̃:/ - fully unspecified vowel surfaces as /i, ɪ/ TONES - H, L - floating tone causes downstep on following H SYLLABLE STRUCTURE AND MINIMAL WORD - V, CV, CVC - Coda just: /b, t, d, g, m, n, f, ʃ, dʒ, r, ṛ/ - minimal word is bimoraic - most words consitst of a root prefixed with vowel - if no prefix, vowel surfaces as bimoraic PHONOLOGICAL PROCESSES - no vowel/consonant clusters -- processes are triggered to prevent CC/VV - VOWEL DELETION -- V[-high] --> 0 / _ ##V -- Verb + Object - VOWEL ASSIMILATION -- also V##V -- replaces own features with the other V's features -- mora stays -- Noun + Modifier - GLIDE FORMATION -- V##V with high vowels -- labialises/palatalises preceeding consonant - VOWEL EPENTHESIS -- C##C -- inserted vowel: high, front/back harmony with preceding vowel, toneless, surface with the tone of preceding TBU - /g, m/ deletion -- if C1 is /g, m/, it gets deleted - /m/ DELETION AT syntactic boundaries 2.5.2 MORPHOLOGY NOUNS - noun class prefix (mono/bimoraic oral vowel) - syntactic tone: L - nominal use, H - predicative use) 2.5.3 SYNTAX - NP: N-Modifier -- POSS-X-X-X-DEM - Main Clause: mainly SVO -- Subj can be dropped 3 TONE IN IKAAN 3.1 PREVIOUS RESEARCH - Abiodun's analysis (problems) -- too many processes, a lot of exceptions -- L either default tone or floating L --- no underlying L -- subscribing to OCP + maintaining contrasting H and HH 3.2 BASICS - functional load of tone low in lexicon (not many minmal pairs) but high in grammar TBU - mora - /m/ mora, /n, ŋm/ not moraic 3.3 TONES AND ALLOTONES - Surface: H, M, L, X - Underlying: H [H, M] ; L [L, X] - No mid tone becauseː -- Distributionː No M after L -- Ceiling effect -- Cumulation (terracing effect) - initial !H is accounted for by initial floating L - X because: -- X just in phrase final position. H is not affected -- syntax triggers lowering CONTOUR TONES - just tonal sequences because: -- mora TBU, sequences just on bimoraic syllables -- epenthetic vowels just copy the last part of the sequence -- no downstep on LH -- contours after dropping intervocalic n 3.4 TONAL MELODIES - make grammar more economical - tone copying for unassociated tones -- violates OCP -- spreading would not result in floating tones when deleting a vowel -- copying does - L deletion at the word boundary (just for melodies!) 5.2.1 IMPERATIVE - verbs underlyingly toneless? -- different imperatives may be an argument against this, but -- imperative melodies inferable from long verb form. - irregular NFUT form: L 5.2.2 NONFUT - bimoraic prefixes have the two first tones of melody - prefixes lexically bimoraic - tonal melody is fully autosegmental 5.2.3 HAB - OCP(L) and H docking 5.2.4 ALTERNATIVE EXPLANATIONS - melody is lexically distinguished (mono- vs bimoraic stems) - moras are counted by grammar -- Prob: not autosegmental any more!
record.research-notes: 2.5 GRAMMATICAL BACKGROUND 2.5.1 PHONOLOGY CONSONANTS - only pulmonic - no voiced fricatives - voiced and voiceless approximants - s, l, ŋ only in loan words - p in loan words and in òpú 'ten' - dʒ may also be palatal plosive VOWELS - height, fronting, contrastive ATR value, length and nasality - all contrasting possibilities of oral/nasal, +/-ATR, long short attested except /ẽ:, ʊ̃:/ - fully unspecified vowel surfaces as /i, ɪ/ TONES - H, L - floating tone causes downstep on following H SYLLABLE STRUCTURE AND MINIMAL WORD - V, CV, CVC - Coda just: /b, t, d, g, m, n, f, ʃ, dʒ, r, ṛ/ - minimal word is bimoraic - most words consitst of a root prefixed with vowel - if no prefix, vowel surfaces as bimoraic PHONOLOGICAL PROCESSES - no vowel/consonant clusters -- processes are triggered to prevent CC/VV - VOWEL DELETION -- V[-high] --> 0 / _ ##V -- Verb + Object - VOWEL ASSIMILATION -- also V##V -- replaces own features with the other V's features -- mora stays -- Noun + Modifier - GLIDE FORMATION -- V##V with high vowels -- labialises/palatalises preceeding consonant - VOWEL EPENTHESIS -- C##C -- inserted vowel: high, front/back harmony with preceding vowel, toneless, surface with the tone of preceding TBU - /g, m/ deletion -- if C1 is /g, m/, it gets deleted - /m/ DELETION AT syntactic boundaries 2.5.2 MORPHOLOGY NOUNS - noun class prefix (mono/bimoraic oral vowel) - syntactic tone: L - nominal use, H - predicative use) 2.5.3 SYNTAX - NP: N-Modifier -- POSS-X-X-X-DEM - Main Clause: mainly SVO -- Subj can be dropped 3 TONE IN IKAAN 3.1 PREVIOUS RESEARCH - Abiodun's analysis (problems) -- too many processes, a lot of exceptions -- L either default tone or floating L --- no underlying L -- subscribing to OCP + maintaining contrasting H and HH 3.2 BASICS - functional load of tone low in lexicon (not many minmal pairs) but high in grammar TBU - mora - /m/ mora, /n, ŋm/ not moraic 3.3 TONES AND ALLOTONES - Surface: H, M, L, X - Underlying: H [H, M] ; L [L, X] - No mid tone becauseː -- Distributionː No M after L -- Ceiling effect -- Cumulation (terracing effect) - initial !H is accounted for by initial floating L - X because: -- X just in phrase final position. H is not affected -- syntax triggers lowering CONTOUR TONES - just tonal sequences because: -- mora TBU, sequences just on bimoraic syllables -- epenthetic vowels just copy the last part of the sequence -- no downstep on LH -- contours after dropping intervocalic n 3.4 TONAL MELODIES - make grammar more economical - tone copying for unassociated tones -- violates OCP -- spreading would not result in floating tones when deleting a vowel -- copying does - L deletion at the word boundary (just for melodies!) 5.2.1 IMPERATIVE - verbs underlyingly toneless? -- different imperatives may be an argument against this, but -- imperative melodies inferable from long verb form. - irregular NFUT form: L 5.2.2 NONFUT - bimoraic prefixes have the two first tones of melody - prefixes lexically bimoraic - tonal melody is fully autosegmental 5.2.3 HAB - OCP(L) and H docking 5.2.4 ALTERNATIVE EXPLANATIONS - melody is lexically distinguished (mono- vs bimoraic stems) - moras are counted by grammar -- Prob: not autosegmental any more!

pdf-urls.url: internal-pdf://Salffner - 2010 - Tone in the phonology, lexicon and grammar of Ikaan. PhD Thesis.pdf

record.label: AIKA;Ikaan;Nigeria;Tone
record.abstract:
This thesis investigates the forms, functions and behaviour of tone in the phonology,lexicon, morphosyntax and the phonology-grammar interfaces in Ikaan (Benue-Congo, Nigeria). The analysis is based on an annotated audio corpus of recordings from 29 speakers collected during ten months of fieldwork complemented with participant observation and informally collected data.

The study demonstrates that tone operates at a wide range of levels of linguistic analysis in Ikaan. As phonemes, tones distinguish meaning in minimal pairs and are subject to phonological rules. As morphemes, tones and tonal melodies bear meaning in inflection, derivation and reduplication. In the syntax, tones mark phrase boundaries. At the phonology-semantics interface, constructionspecific constraints on the tonal representation distinguish between predicating and referential nominal modifiers. Combined with intonation and voicing, tones distinguish between statements and morphosyntactically identical yes/no questions.

The research identifies a range of unusual tonal behaviours in Ikaan. The two tones H and L follow markedly different phonologies. In the association of lexical and grammatical tonal melodies, H must be realised whereas non-associated L are deleted. Formerly associated but de-linked L however are not deleted but remain floating. The OCP is found to apply to L but not to H. H is downstepped after floating L but not after overt L. In addition, three different locations of downstep are attested which correlate with different syntactic and semantic properties of the respective constructions. In two of these downstep locations, a leftward copying process occurs in addition to a generally applicable rightward copying process so that two directions of copying occur.

The thesis concludes by discussing the implications of the Ikaan findings for the wider theoretical discourse with respect to the status of the OCP, the directionality of spreading and the modelling of downstep.

record.notes: · ni is intuitively analysed by speakers as a verb · used in questions, focus, copula sentences · Function 1: Focus o Sentence initial NPs are focused, i. e. isolated from the post-ni sentence and coded sentence initially to give them prominence. · Function 2: Copula o Equative and Presentative · Function 3: Content questions: o follows the wh-phrase - Function 3: emphatic reading to the whole event
